read_landmarks module¶

read_landmarks.axisEqual3D(ax)[source]¶

Transforms an ax object into one with equal scales.

Parameters

ax --

Returns

Return type

read_landmarks.find_app_coordinates(worksheet)[source]¶

Finds the app coordinate from the worksheet. The output is a dictionary of APP landmarks with keys:

  • 'RASIS' : np.array shape (,3) location of the right anterior illiac spine on the triangular mesh definining the anterior pelvic plane

  • 'LASIS' : np.array shape (,3) location of the left anterior illiac spine on the triangular mesh definining the anterior pelvic plane

  • 'RTUB' : np.array shape (,3) location of the right acetabulum on the triangular mesh definining the anterior pelvic plane

  • 'LTUB' : np.array shape (,3) location of the left acetabulum on the triangular mesh definining the anterior

Parameters

worksheet -- object returned by openpyxl.load_workbook().active

Returns

dictionary of app landmarks.

Return type

dict

read_landmarks.find_coordinates_from_worksheet(worksheet, my_dict, key='Right Ant Lat')[source]¶

extracts the socket coordinates from an excelt sheet by using the coordinates where the search should start

Parameters

  • worksheet -- loaded excel file by pyopenxl

  • my_dict -- dictionary containing column and row indices for where the information can be found

  • key -- Which side and part of the socket to look for choices : "Right Ant Lat", "Right Post Lat", "Left Ant Lat", "Left Post Lat" these are keys of the dictionary output by find_structure_coordinate_socket

Returns

np.array shape (N,3) or None if nothing is found

read_landmarks.find_imOriginSpacing_from_worksheet(worksheet)[source]¶

Reads the image origin and spacing from the worksheet corresponding to a landmark xlsx file from the landmark data

Parameters

worksheet -- worksheet loaded from openpyxl.load_workbook().active

Returns

list of origin,spacing which are both np array of shape [1,3] showing the location of the image origin and

the spacing of the origin

read_landmarks.find_structure_coordinate_socket(worksheet)[source]¶

Finds the coordinates of landmarks from an excel file. this assumes that the excel file does not follow any specific format and is arranged in a disorderly manner.

Parameters

worksheet -- object returned by openpyxl.load_workbook().active

Returns

dictionary of landmarks column and row where these coordinates point to where one should iterate to get

the landmarks

read_landmarks.plot_landmark(path='./data/Segmentation_and_landmarks_raw/UCLH - Controls', k=10)[source]¶

plots the landmark on top of the stl file representing the pelvis surface for the folder UCLH - Controls. The folder structure for path is as follows:

| path
| ├── C4
| │   ├── Left
| │   │   ├── C4_LPEL.mha
| │   │   ├── C4_LPEL.vtk
| │   │   ├── C4_LPEL.stl
| │   └── Right
| │   │   ├── C4_RPEL.mha
| │   │   ├── C4_RPEL.vtk
| │   │   ├── C4_RPEL.stl
| │   └── landmarks.xlsx

The ladmakrs are saved in landmarks.xlsx.

Parameters

  • path (str) -- path to folder containing the raw data.

  • k (int) -- index showing which folder to select from path

read_landmarks.plot_landmark_uclh_controls(path='./data/Segmentation_and_landmarks_raw/UCLH - Controls', k=10)[source]¶

plots the landmark on top of the stl file representing the pelvis surface for the folder UCLH - Controls. The folder structure for path is as follows:

| path
| ├── C4
| │   ├── Left
| │   │   ├── C4_LPEL.mha
| │   │   ├── C4_LPEL.vtk
| │   │   ├── C4_LPEL.stl
| │   └── Right
| │   │   ├── C4_RPEL.mha
| │   │   ├── C4_RPEL.vtk
| │   │   ├── C4_RPEL.stl
| │   └── landmarks.xlsx

The ladmakrs are saved in landmarks.xlsx.

Parameters

  • path (str) -- path to folder containing the raw data.

  • k (int) -- index showing which folder to select from path

Returns

Return type
